comment._content: Your observation is an interesting one. The well dressed adults (overcoats, shoes and hats) on a cold damp looking day, is a harsh contrast to the young barefoot child with just a jumper and shorts. When browsing through Mount Saint Lawrence’s Cemetery burial records, it’s therefore not surprising to see a high ratio of children dying young at that time. Many tough kids had to survive Frank McCourt’s Limerick.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: That poor man will never be able to pull that contraption all the way to Ardnacrusha!  A factor in it's positioning is that most of the houses in Georgian Limerick had coal cellars that went out under the streets and might not have borne the weight of the Steam Shovel.  You will note that it is in the centre of the roadway where it was strongest.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/42126491@N06] Well, it just struck me that here we have a behemoth of modern technology, imported from Germany, lumbering off to what was one of the largest engineering projects in the world at that time - and a boy barefoot on the street watching it pass by. While I'm always wary of making assumptions about lack of shoes, in this case, he really does look poor juxtaposed with some of the men...

comment.author: 42126491@N06
comment._content: ‘Twas one thing running barefoot around Plassey in the summertime but to see that kid exposed to the elements like that in 1928 foreboded something bad. That kid would have needed a very robust immune system, especially things like common bacterial infections in an era where antibiotics did not exist, were often enough a fatal blow. There was nothing nostalgic about barefeet, you were either sparing the wear and tear of one’s shoes or did not have a pair at all. Maybe one or two Limerick people would have had a genuine personal gripe with McCourt over the way he wrote about their family. My own working class family roots were those of the overcrowded lanes of the Irishtown and Boherbuoy areas of the city. Child mortality hit most families who lived in those lanes, similar to the loss of McCourt’s three young siblings. His book hit a nerve with those who experienced that, his detractors are probably in denial (shame) with the poverty that was associated with many parts of Limerick. Here is a fine photo of school kids having a bottle of milk and bun in their break taken on Mary Street. There is a least three of them barefoot.
